div.script: $(document).ready(function() {CheckScript('ModuleView');CheckScript('Mustache'); });

p.span: Dear D11 Families,

br.span: You may have heard late yesterday Gov. Jared Polis announced all schools will remain closed for in-person learning throughout the remainder of the school year. The Governors order clearly means School District 11 will continue distance learning throughout the rest of this school year and we will not be reopening our schools for in-person learning. We are now working with our principals and leadership teams to create schedules for staff and students to close out the school year, including schedules to return materials and pick up personal belongings. Communication of these plans will follow in the coming weeks.

I thank all of our students, families, and staff for your grace and patience during our deployment of distance learning. Although this is not how any of us envisioned this school year ending, the health and safety of everyone in our D11 community is our top priority. Thank you.
Yours in Partnership,
Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

div.p:
Dear D11 Families,
During our time of distance learning, I am continually reminded of the dedication of our educators, reaching out and providing not only academic guidance, but social emotional support, too. I admire our students for their grit and determination to remain lifelong learners in this environment. Our families have been the backbone of support for their children as we have all learned to navigate this new normal.
Today though, I reflect on the indignity of this virus and how it has taken away so many celebrations from our students. From our fifth graders and our eighth graders who have been looking forward to their final days at their schools before moving up to the next level, to our beloved seniors whove been dreaming of their senior year and all of the final high school celebrations like prom, your final spring sports season, your final musical or play, and most importantly, your graduation, our hearts break for you.
As we await updated guidance from Colorado Governor Jared Polis and supporting health agencies regarding the current stay-at-home order, we have made the decision to move forward with planning for virtual graduation ceremonies, for now. In order for us to produce the virtual ceremonies in time to air on the dates graduations were originally scheduled in May, we must begin this process now. Nationwide, health experts predict large-scale gatherings such as conferences, sporting events, and even graduations, wont be safe to attend until Fall 2021. If this guidance changes, we will do everything possible to schedule in-person graduation ceremonies based on data showing we may resume large-scale gatherings. Weve heard from a number of students, parents, staff members, and community members offering various suggestions on how to move forward with graduations. Making this decision was extremely difficult because there are so many different creative and innovative ideas, but we must do what is safest for everyone in our community. More details regarding these plans will be communicated in the coming weeks.

p.br:
I know you are disappointed, upset, confused, and sad to forfeit these monumental events because of COVID-19. Our seniors have worked extremely hard over the past 13 years to get to this point. I also know how resilient you are to adversity and how just being a part of the Class of 2020 will create a bond among you for the rest of your lives! Maya Angelou once said, You may encounter many defeats, but you must not be defeated. In fact, it may be necessary to encounter the defeats, so you can know who you are, what you can rise from, how you can still come out of it.
The wisdom in her words demonstrates life is not all made of pleasant experiences; we all learn from adversity, its a chance for our character to grow, and to show how our resolve will move us forward. I am tremendously proud of all of your achievements and I know it will be the Class of 2020 that makes a profound impact on our world.
Yours in Partnership,
Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

div.p: Dear D11 Families,

As we conclude the first official week of D11 distance learning, we continue to hear the feedback from our families and educators on ways we may support our students both academically, and socially/emotionally. Thank you to everyone who submitted questions for the D11 presentation on Fostering Student Social Emotional Well Being. You may view that presentationhere.

On Thursday, we started mobile bus stop feeding sites, in addition to the 12 school distribution sites. These sites distribute meals during the same time as our other locations, 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. The new mobile locations are:
85 Sunflower Rd (The Northwest corner of Sunflower Rd. and N. Cascade Ave)

Rosemont at Shadow Mountain Apartments
220 Shadow Ridge Grove
Northwest corner of the parking lot at VanTeylingen & N. Carefree Dr. (3400 N. Carefree Drive)

The Springs Mobile Home Park
1095 Western Dr

A-1 Mobile Villeage
1025 Garner St

We have identified the families in need of devices for distance learning and will begin communicating plans for deployment with those identified families next week. Much of the communication will come directly from the schools. We thank our IT division for their work on this process.

Finally, we have had many discussions this week with students and staff members regarding graduations. Please know plans are being developed to address the many questions we are receiving regarding graduations, and more communication on the finalized plans will be sent at the end of next week.
Thank you for continued grace and patience as we work together to do what is best for all D11 students!
Dear D11 Families,

This week has been a learning experience for so many of us as we navigate the new ways of teaching and learning remotely. The highlights of this week for me have been the conversations I've had with students either via phone or video chat focused not just on education, but this "new normal" way of life! I am encouraged to see so many pictures shared with me on many platforms of our students smiling from their home work stations, chatting with their teachers via WebEx meetings, and adapting to learning outside of the classroom. While I know challenges exist, I also know hope continues to grow as we encourage one another, demonstrating grace and patience.

Today, several Denver area school districts announced they will cancel all in-person learning, continuing distance learning for the remainder of the school year. The Pikes Peak area school districts are not yet ready to make a decision to cancel the remainder of the year.

We will continue supporting our students and their families with remote learning. We will also continue working closely with our Governor and our local health department, and lean on their guidance for our planning efforts. Plans seem to change daily, and sometimes hourly, but we will keep in touch with you and share our plans as they are implemented.
Things to keep in mind for next week as we embark on another week of remote learning:

Keep in contact with your child(ren)s teacher(s) and be sure you are communicating your familys needs for continued learning from home.
Continue to view theD11 Distance Learning website, which also has many social/emotional resources, as well as tools and How-To tips for students and families.
We understand remote learning will not take the form of a typical in-person school day, especially when it comes to time. Remote learning days will typically be much shorter than the in-person instructional days. Its okay to take breaks, allow your child to take breaks, and be patient with your child and the teachers. We are all learning together.
The District Instructional Technology team has been working to develop a technology deployment plan for students in need. The goal is NOT to provide a laptop for every student at home, but rather identify families without access to a computer. We anticipate starting to deploy these devices, based on prioritized needs, starting April 13. We plan to communicate to these identified families regarding pick-up processes starting April 10.
This week, our school-based teams worked to identify families who need hard copy or paper educational materials. Those materials will be prepared and delivered to identified families via U.S. Mail.
We continue to expand our food distribution sites and will still provide breakfast and lunch combined grab-and-go bags, Mondays through Fridays from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the following sites:

o Doherty HS
o Russell MS
o Mitchell HS
o Swigert MS
o RJWAC HS
o North MS
o Mann MS
o Coronado HS
o West ES
o Adams ES
o Monroe ES (new)
o Rogers ES (new)

I hope all of our families and employees get a chance to disconnect this weekend and get some much-needed rest. As a district, we are looking forward to some uplifting scheduled virtual events next week. We encourage everyone to participate in the first-ever Distance-Learning Virtual Spirit Week next week, organized entirely by our D11 student social media ambassadors. Details are in the attachment. Also, several of our families and staff are taking part in the #BeTheLightCO challenge as seen inthis video. I know the phone calls Ive made this week have made a positive difference in my days.
Its my honor to serve as your superintendent and I know we are all in this together. We will persevere and come out stronger, gaining new knowledge that will serve us in the future.
Yours in Partnership,

Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

p.span: Dear D11 Families,

br.span: Earlier today, during a press conference, Colorado Governor Jared Polis announced the suspension of in-person learning across our state through April 30, 2020. This order aligns with the Presidents guidelines announced earlier this week.

Our district will continue our current path of conducting distance learning. At this time, we do not know if we will return after April 30, 2020, or if the suspension of in-person learning will continue.
Please know, we continue to work closely with the Governor and are following the recommendations of state and regional health professionals. As we learn more, we will share updates.
Yours in Partnership,
Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

p.span: Dear D11 Families and Staff Members,

br.span: We're living in unprecedented and challenging times. In School District 11, we are committed to supporting the social, emotional and academic well-being of our students. We want you to know we're going to do this together as a D11 family. The D11 Distance Learning website found at

has many opportunities outlined by grade level and learning style. Official school site D11 Distance Learning will begin April 7th. However, students are encouraged to continue to engage in learning activities throughout this week.

Rest assured, we understand this is not going to replace the human relationship we have with our students on a day to day basis. This week our primary goal is to re-establish what a distance learning relationship will look like. You will also be receiving a phone call from your students teacher(s), helping to understand what learning styles your students have, as well as what opportunities will engage them most.

We know in this distance learning framework we are going to heavily depend on technology. And even though many of our students and families have accessible technology in your homes, we recognize many of our students do not have adequate resources for technology support. We will be working with many of our community partners to collaborate and ensure we can get as much technology into the homes of our families that need it most. In the coming weeks District 11 will be distributing laptops, Chromebooks, and a variety of other devices to ensure our students can actively engage during this time. Information on this device distribution will be forthcoming. We ask for your patience at this time and know we are working with our students who do not have a device accessible to them at this time.

We continue to serve thousands of grab-and-go meals at ten locations across the District. Our Food and Nutrition Services crews have made this operation possible and there are so many students who are dependent on this as they may not have food security at home. These employees, along with so many others across D11, are the backbone of our operations. Thank you so much for your dedication to our mission to empower the whole student to profoundly impact our world. I want to take this time to thank many of our dedicated D11 staff. To that end, we have many of our custodial staff who have dedicated their time to ensuring our school buildings are cleaned, sanitized and ready for our students to return at some point. And I cannot thank them enough for their hard work and commitment to ensuring not only our students safety, but that of the entire D11 community.

I recognize these are real challenging times for us. But in D11, we are strong. As your Superintendent, with the support of thousands of our staff, we will continue to ensure your students are supported academically, socially and emotionally.
Yours in Partnership,
Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

p.span: Dear D11 Families,

br.span: As we near the end of spring break, we wanted to update you on information that will be helpful for next week's distance learning. We are looking forward to remotely engaging with our students next week and teachers/school staff members will be reaching out to contact each family.
To ensure all of your district contact information is updated, please log into the D11 Loop and make sure we have all your current contact information. Here's how:

p.span: 1. Log into the D11 Loop:

br.span: 2. Parents/guardians use your Q Parent Connection PIN and password. If you forgot your Parent Connection information, visit the Q Parent Connect portal,
and click on "Need your login information?" An email will be sent to your primary email address as listed in Q.
3. If you want to receive notifications via text message, please be sure to add a Text/SMS number on the account tab. Text messages are always an opt-in option.

We continue to gather information about the technology needs of our families. Thank you to everyone who has taken the Distance Learning and Resource Survey. If you haven't taken it and would like to, click here:

Finally, we received updated clarification from Gov. Polis and the Colorado Department of Education regarding yesterdays executive order implementing a statewide stay-at-home order. The public health order was updated to include a number of critical services. For K-12 public and private schools, we are designating mission critical staff for the purpose of providing meals, housing, facilitating or providing materials for distance learning, and providing other essential services to students. We will continue to provide students with the combined breakfast/lunch grab-and-go lunches from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., weekdays at the following school sites:

div.p:
Doherty HS
Russell MS
Mitchell HS
Swigert MS
RJWAC HS
North MS
Mann MS
Coronado HS
West ES
Adams ES
It is our goal to support our D11 families with community resources and information. For a complete list of linked resources we've sent to date, visithttps://www.d11.org/covid19. Thank you.

br.span: While today is officially the first day of spring break, we recognize very little feels normal right now. As a district, we prioritize learning and providing the necessary environment for students to thrive and achieve their academic best. However, during this week and the days after, we want to provide resources and access to supports that will help families navigate the fear, uncertainty, anxiety, shame, and guilt that often accompanies challenging times. As we collectively take a deep breath, remember there is no right way to parent during a pandemic. All of us are doing the very best for your families and should you need additional supports, the District wants to provide you the following community resources. Once we return from spring break on March 30, additional staff supports will be available and more information on how to access these will be sent to our families.

br.span: Colorado Springs School District 11

p.span: Dear D11 Families, Staff Members, and Community,

br.span: This first week of distance learning and closure of all of our D11 schools and buildings has definitely been a challenge. We want to thank you for your continued patience as our D11 teams work to put processes in place so we may continue to support the learning and overall health and wellness of our D11 students.

Next week is spring break, and while this year's spring break will look much different for everyone, we are encouraging our families to disconnect and take a break. The distance learning website is still accessible (

), but no assignments will be given for next week. Teachers may not be in contact with students over spring break, however, we do have some updates to share regarding food distribution sites starting next week.
* D11 will continue with food distribution starting Monday, March 23, for the rest of the break and until further notice.

* We will be adding a breakfast to every sack lunch for the students to eat the following morning. We have also been approved to give extra combined bagged breakfasts and lunches to cover the weekend. Those will go out with Friday's pickup.
* We are adding Adams Elementary School to our food distribution site list.
* We are exploring adding mobile sites to some of the areas on the edge of the district. More details will come as those plans are determined.
The following are the updated D11 food distribution sites:
Doherty HS
Russell MS
Mitchell HS
Swigert MS
RJWAC HS
North MS
Mann MS
Coronado HS
West ES
Adams ES
You may receive updates from D11 over spring break, so please continue to watch for these notifications. All updates are posted to our D11 COVID-19 planning website at

. There are some other linked resources on that page you may find helpful during this time. We are grateful for our overwhelmingly supportive D11 community and value our partnerships with all of our families, employees, and community members. Thank you.

p.span: D11 and the Pikes Peak Area Superintendents Support Governors Order to Extend School Closures

br.span: To help mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus in Colorado, on Wednesday, March 18, 2020, Colorado Governor Jared Polis ordered all public and private schools across the state suspend in-person learning from March 23 to April 17.

The executive order directs Colorado school districts and the Charter School Institute to make every effort to provide alternative learning opportunities during this time while taking into account the needs of local communities. This order also directs the Commissioner of Education to issue guidance to support P-12 school systems in developing and implementing plans to assist families and students in accessing alternative learning, providing free and reduced lunch and breakfast, and offering waivers for instructional time as appropriate.

Protecting the health of all Coloradoans is our top priority, and moving to online learning and other ways to support learning at home is absolutely the right thing to do, said Education Commissioner Katy Anthes. We know school leaders, educators and families will have a lot of questions about how to support their students learning at home during this unprecedented time. The department is working on guidance and developing resources to support our schools and students, and it will be available very soon.
The Governor made this order via press release this evening. Read it online here:

School districts in the Pikes Peak Region had already decided to close school buildings through March 27. This order will extend that timeframe. At this time, and per this order, students will return to school on Monday, April 20.

We appreciate the Governors guidance and leadership during this challenging time. Our local districts are meeting tomorrow and in the coming days and will provide individual communities more specifics after those meetings, said Dr. Walt Cooper, a representative for the Pikes Peak Area Superintendents.

Educators and leadership in the Pikes Peak Region have already started working on how to provide educational resources for students and families, and school districts are planning for how to ensure that students can continue to receive breakfast and lunch while schools are closed.

Pikes Peak Area Superintendents emphasize this is a new reality for all and it will require all of us working together in support of children in the Pikes Peak Region. We know this information brings both certainty and uncertainty for the weeks ahead. Wed ask that we allow each other a measure of grace, as we develop plans for what school looks like in the weeks ahead. Now, more than ever, we must work together for the benefit of our children and our community. We thank you for being patient as we navigate this new reality.

div.p: Dear D11 Families, Staff Members, and Community,

We continue to update you with the most relevant information as it pertains to D11. This continues to be a very challenging time for many, and we thank you for your ongoing patience as we navigate many situations that arise. Here's the latest on what we know to date:

We are aware of the Governor's announcement yesterday to close many public gathering places. Our leadership teams are in ongoing conversations with local officials and area school districts regarding the possibility of having to extend our closure beyond spring break. Rest assured, we will communicate with you as soon as a decision is made.

D11 continues our distance learning opportunities and we ask families to work with their students for continuous learning throughout this closure. You may access the distance learning website by clicking here. We learned today the Colorado Department of Education will pause administration of end-of-the-year assessments, including CMAS. Our team is in communication with CDE to learn what this means specifically for D11.

You may be aware that the Colorado High School Activities Association, or CHSAA, extended their moratorium on spring sports and activities they govern through April 18. This does impact our student athletes and we've asked coaches to reach out to their teams with any additional communication, specific to their sport.

Our Food and Nutrition Services department continues to operate our nine grab-and-go food distribution sites. Students who get meals tomorrow may request two meals in the event we have inclement weather on Thursday, and we are unable to have staff handing out meals.

Finally, the special Board of Education meeting scheduled for tomorrow will be a virtual meeting. The public may view the meeting on Comcast channel 16, CenturyLink 8004, and StratusIQ 73. The meeting will also be streaming live on the D11 website: https://www.d11.org/TV

We know this is may be a stressful time for so many of our families and staff members. Please remember we have many resources linked to our COVID-19 planning and preparedness website at https://www.d11.org/covid19. We thank you for your ongoing support of our mission to ensure continuous education for all of our students.

Dear D11 Families, Staff Members, and Community,
The COVID-19 situation continues to change and D11 is taking additional measures to protect our students and employees. At this time, no D11 staff members or students have tested positive for COVID-19, but some of our staff members and students have been in direct contact with laboratory confirmed positive COVID-19 cases in the broader Colorado Springs community, and these cases will likely increase over time. We are aware of some staff members and families who have self-isolated as of last week, and while we cannot share specific details due to privacy laws, the following steps have been taken to mitigate the transmission of COVID-19:
1. For everyones safety, all D11 buildings will only be open for mission critical staff essential to operations during the closure.
2. D11 facilities crews are beginning the processes to deep clean and disinfect all schools.
3. The distance learning website has been established and students/families may access it by clicking this link: https://www.d11.org/DistanceLearning
4. Food distribution sites will begin today at nine D11 sites from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Those sites are:

Doherty High School
Russell Middle School
Mitchell High School
Swigert Middle School
The RJWAC Campus
North Middle School
Mann Middle School
Coronado High School
West Elementary School
Additional community food distribution sites may be viewed in the attached documents below. We are working to set up technology for virtual board of education meetings that will allow for public participation. Although not ideal, these meetings will allow for board work to continue. We will provide more details when this plan is in place.
Our community continues to provide amazing resources and we will be posting some of those community resources on our COVID-19 website, https://www.d11.org/Covid19. Please check this website regularly for up-to-date information and helpful links. We thank you for your continued support and patience during this time. We extend our sincere compassion to our students, employees, and D11 community. We know so many people are working tirelessly to support our mission and we are grateful for this support.

Dear D11 Families and Staff,
We thank you for your patience during this time when information continues to change rapidly. School District 11 will continue to provide information so you and your family may plan accordingly.
Here are updated decisions made at this point:

ul.li: All after school and evening activities throughout the District will be cancelled through April 6, to align with the Colorado High School Activities Association directives.
All district and school sponsored travel for both students and employees will be cancelled through March 31. Any travel scheduled beyond March 31 is suspended until further notice.

We know families and employees may have personal trips planned in the near future. We ask that you exercise caution and protect yourself during your travels, following the guidance from CDC found here.
All district rentals will be cancelled, including any contracted daycare facilities such as Adventure Club, effective March 13, 2020 until further notice.
All district-level events in district facilities will be cancelled, including the World Cafes originally scheduled for March 17 and 19, 2020.

div.p: The District will provide one bagged meal per person, per day the week of March 16-20, Mon-Fri, for children ages 0-18 years of age from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the following sites:

Doherty High School
Russell Middle School
Mitchell High School
Swigert Middle School
The RJWAC Campus
North Middle School
Mann Middle School
Coronado High School
West Elementary School

The District is developing tools to help students guide their own learning with the content they are currently learning in their classes.During this unexpected closure, our D11 students may reach out for guidance, help, and even confirmation that they are on the right track with their work. Teachers are encouraged to provide assistance when able during what would normally be a school day, so long as it does not somehow create hardship.
Again, this is a rapidly developing situation and we will continue to update you regularly. You may see all updates on the www.d11.org website under the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Updates and Resources link.

br.span: Starting Monday, March 16, Colorado Springs School District 11 will join El Paso County school districts in closing all school facilities for a period of 14 days. This necessary action is an attempt to slow the spread of the COVID-19 infection. The closure will be from March 16 through March 27, which includes our already scheduled Spring Break. We will reassess the situation as we get closer to that end date, and decide if students and staff should return on Monday, March 30. Superintendents will be calling on the Colorado Department of Education for flexibility on mandatory seat time and state testing requirements.

br.span: The decision to close our school district was extremely difficult, but it was made out of an abundance of caution and in consultation with superintendents throughout El Paso County. We know closing our schools will have a significant impact on our families, but we also believe strong, urgent action must be taken to prevent the spread of this disease and to protect lives.

br.span: We are facing an unprecedented public health crisis in our community. In our response to COVID-19, we must depend on the factual information from local, state, and federal agencies, as well elected officials, and make decisions that protect the health of students, staff and families in our community. In light of Governor Polis declaration of a state of emergency in Colorado, and the rapidly growing number of confirmed cases in Colorado, we must take swift action to protect public health.

br.span: Colorado Springs School District 11

div.p:
Dear D11 Families and Staff Members,
As the global COVID-19 information continues to develop, I want to keep you informed on our planning efforts in School District 11. We continue to receive many questions regarding absences, both for illness and precaution, as well as questions regarding guidance to close schools. The following information will answer many of the questions we've received to date. We continue to receive updated information from local, state, and federal agencies and we post regular updates on thewww.d11.orghome page under the "D11 Planning and Preparation for COVID-19" link.
Excused Absences
Question:What length of time will we excuse students because of concerns over COVID-19?

p.br: Families who have students with pre-existing health conditions that compromise their immune systems may excuse their students through the declared state of emergency as enacted by the Governor. School assignments for students absent during this time will follow our current excused absence practices.

Families who wish to keep their children home for preventative measures may do so up to two weeks (14 academic days). They will not be penalized, as their absences will be counted as excused. School assignments for students absent during this time will follow our current excused absence practices.

span.style: font-size: x-large;

div.p: Question:Is the District considering closure and under what circumstances would that occur?
Answers:State ordered closure criteria

ul.li: Any school in Colorado with one confirmed case of COVID-19 in a staff member or student will close for a minimum of 72 hours for cleaning and social distancing.
Any schools that are closed will partner with their local public health agency to conduct further COVID-19 testing.

Any school with two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in a staff member or student within a 30-day period requires a second minimum 72-hour closure (for a total of 144 hours) for cleaning, testing and public health investigation.
Any school with three confirmed cases of COVID-19 in staff member or students within a 30-day period requires a closure for a minimum of 14 days.

If three schools in a district have confirmed cases of COVID-19 within a 30-day period, all schools within the district are required to close for a minimum of 14 days for cleaning, testing and public health investigation.

Other factors to consider when making decisions to close one or more schools, include:
Families with students in multiple buildings
Shared facilities
Shared transportation
Central kitchens
Shared staff

div.p: As always, the safety of our students and staff is our top priority. You will continue to be updated with information from D11 regarding our planning efforts and the impacts of COVID-19 on our school district. Thank you for your support and awareness during this time.

Yours in Partnership,
Dr. Michael J. Thomas, Superintendent
Colorado Springs School District 11

p.span: Dear D11 Families,

br.span: Members of the D11 behavioral health team will once again prepare a presentation that will be recorded and posted on the Distance Learning website. This second presentation will focus on grief during the stay at home order and how we are experiencing many types of grief during this time, including not being with friends and family, reduced access to hobbies, loss of normal daily activities, and loss of student school rituals. This brief 15-20 minute presentation will be followed by questions and answers. If you have questions on this topic, please submit them before tomorrow afternoon by clicking this link:
Once the presentation has been recorded and published, we will send out a link where you may access it to view it.
Thank you.

p.strong: suspending all district-sponsored international and out-of-state travel for all students and staff.
p.span: This is a change from what was previously communicated. This means all trips scheduled and approved, as well as all trips awaiting approval will be cancelled.

p.span: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that cause respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough and shortness of breath. These viruses spread through coughing or sneezing, much like the flu.

h1.aria-label: What happens in the event of a quarantine or closure?
h1.span: What happens in the event of a quarantine or closure?

div.p: D11 will follow the guidance and direction of the El Paso County Public Health agency for any quarantines, closures or other health measures as needed. D11 leadership teams are closely monitoring attendance at our schools. If a school closure is necessary, remote learning plans will be implemented and communicated with families. Currently, our focus remains on prevention.

In the event of a school closure, we will communicate follow-up steps and information. We have plans that are being finalized for e-learning and remote learning. Some of our schools use an online learning tool called Schoology and can deploy online learning curriculum. However, we know not every student has access to a device or internet service at home. We are mindful to ensure the remote learning opportunities are equitable and available for all students.

h1.aria-label: Will my student's absence be excused?
h1.span: Will my student's absence be excused?

p.span: Parents/guardians may call their student's school and excuse their student if they are ill or if the parent/guardian is keeping their student home out of precaution. We are asking families how long they anticipate their student may need to be out of school so we can provide appropriate resources for learning at home.

h1.aria-label: What can I do to stay healthy?
h1.span: What can I do to stay healthy?

p.span: The risk to the general public in the U.S. from this virus is considered low, but just as is recommended for other respiratory viruses, people can protect themselves and others by practicing everyday actions.

h1.aria-label: What are the proactive recommended hygiene tips?
h1.span: What are the proactive recommended hygiene tips?

ul.li: Wash your hands frequently - remember to wash your hands after coughing or sneezing
Wash with soap and water, or if soap and water are unavailable, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol to clean hands
Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue or a long sleeve when coughing and sneezing (per CDC guidance).
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
If you are ill, you should try to distance yourself from others so you do not spread your germs. Distancing includes staying home from work or school when possible.
